awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Efficient Synthesis of Biologically Relevant Cyclic and Polycyclic Terpenoid Compounds Using Alkyne Cyclizations
awd_abstract_narration:
With this CAREER Award, the Synthesis Program supports the research of Professor Wesley A. Chalifoux of the University of Nevada, Reno. Professor Chalifoux develops new chemical tools for the efficient synthesis of biologically active compounds. New methodology developed in this research focuses on the application of ynones for the efficient construction of complex cyclic compounds.  Ynones are substances in which a carbon-carbon triple bond (an alkyne) is connected to a carbon oxygen double bond (a carbonyl group).  This connection enhances chemical reactivity in bimolecular addition reactions. New strategies which are developed in this research have applications in the area of pharmaceutical synthesis and the field of medicine through the generation of biologically-relevant compound libraries. As the educational component of this project, Professor Chalifoux develops an outreach program that focuses on the mentoring of middle and high school students from low-income, first-generation college families as well as groups that are underrepresented in science. The project builds connections with middle and high schools located in the Reno, Nevada area.  Visiting high school students work closely with graduate and undergraduate chemistry students in science-related activities associated with research projects within the Chalifoux group. 

In this project, cyclization and cycloaddition reactions of alkynes and alkynones are explored. This research develops an operationally simple synthetic methodology that converts readily available alkyne, diyne and diene starting materials into complex cyclic and polycyclic target molecules. Simple conjugated alkynes and more complex conjugated and cross-conjugated polyynes are explored as substrates for Diels-Alder cycloaddition reactions. These are further elaborated in multicomponent/tandem cyclization reactions that are designed to generate multiple new carbon-carbon bonds and rings in a single reaction step, with regio- and stereochemical control. This research has broad applications in the area of pharmaceutical synthesis and the field of medicine through the rapid generation of biologically relevant compound libraries. In addition to activities at the middle and high schools, the CAREER Award supports summer research activities at the University of Nevada.  This improves recruitment of underrepresented students into Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematical (STEM) careers and increases retention of students in the sciences.

por.por_cntn:
The general aim of this project was the utilization of high-energy alkyne-containing organic starting materials for the synthesis of cyclic and polycyclic products. Two projects were pursued under this theme: 1) synthesis of terpenoid natural product frameworks and 2) synthesis and study of carbon-rich nanomaterials.

Under project 1, we demonstrated that alkynes can undergo multiple cyclization reactions in a single reaction step to afford highly functionalized terpenoid products. This methodology provides a useful and high-yielding synthetic platform to arrive at advanced intermediates towards more complex targets. The products isolated in our studies were subjected to in silico drug screening and tested for biological activity through Ely Lilly's Open Innovation Drug Discovery Program. Many compounds were also screened through various collaborations and show antimicrobial and antifungal properties.

Under project 2, our group was able to develop and utilize a multialkyne benzannulation strategy to synthesize numerous nanographene scaffolds. Nanographenes are smaller subunits of graphene, a single layer of the sp2-hybridized carbon allotrope known as graphite. Nanographenes have unique properties that make them of interest in various optic and electronic applications. Nanographenes directly produced from graphene/graphite are insoluble and it is hard to control their molecular size and shape, leading to a broad distribution of properties. Our methodology provides atomically precise nanographenes with excellent solubility in common organic solvents. We can vary the size and shape which results in the alteration of the optic and electronic properties. This allows us to tailor the material properties (i.e., absorption, emission, solubility, conductivity, etc.) for particular applications. Our group was the first to demonstrate that [5]armchair graphene nanoribbon (GNR) polymers could be produced using alkyne benzannulations. These GNRs are highly sought after for their use as semiconducting organic materials. For example, our GNRs were used as the photoactive layer in photovoltaic devices where they absorb a broad range of solar light from the ultraviolet region out into the near infrared.

This grant trained thirteen graduate students (seven received PhDs, three received Masters, and three current PhD students), one postdoctoral scholar, twenty undergraduate researchers from UNR, one summer undergraduate intern from CalPoly, and five local high school students.

 


Last Modified: 08/03/2022
Modified by: Wesley A Chalifoux
